The sand gives way to trees, the jingling bottles to dist bells, as A CONVOY OF TWENTY TRUCKS - Red Cross vehicles supply vehicles - snakes along a bumpy hill road.  The wa largely over and the Allies are moving up the country, th supply lines slowly following. 7*.        INT.    RED CROSS TRUCK.    DAY. A young CANADIAN NURSE, HANA, sits in a truck full of pat pays special care to the PATIENT lying in the stretcher a This is the PILOT - now known as THE ENGLISH PATIENT.  A covers the Patient's face and body.  They have the qualit tattoo, magenta and green-black.  The hair has largely go effect is curious, lassoing his features, the strong nose liquid.  It's a warrior's face.  But he has no physical s coughs violently as the trucks shudders along the road. 8*.        EXT.    ITALIAN HILL ROAD.    DAY. A JEEP pulls out of the line and approaches the Red Cross containing Hana and the Patient.  The horn blows and Hana see it contains her best friend, JAN.  TWO YOUNG SOLDIERS one driving, both grinning.  Jan signals for Hana's atten
There's meant to be lace in the next village - the boys are taking me.
I'm not sewing anything else.
(mischievously)
You don't have any money, do you?   Just in case there's silk.
No!

Hana, I know you do! Hana leans under the tarpaulin, holding some DOLLARS.  Th hers and Jan's - reach for each other as the vehicles bum by side.  They laugh at the effort.  Jan's GOLD BRACELET sun and glints.
I'm not sewing anything else for you!
(getting the money)

I love you. The Jeep accelerates away.  Hana sighs to the patient. Suddenly AN EXPLOSION shatters the calm as the jeep runs The jeep is THROWN into the air.  The convoy halts and th soldiers run back pulling people out of the vehicles.  Ha other way, towards the accident, until she is prevented f a soldier. 9*.        EXT.    ITALIAN HILL ROAD.    LATER. -- and there's still chaos as two SAPPERS arrive on motor of them, a SIKH, wears a turban. The motorcycles arrive at the front of the convoy.  A nur helping a doctor, OLIVER, attend to the injured driver. bodies are covered with blankets.  There's blood everywhe and his colleague pull out the paraphernalia of their bom equipment. 10        EXT.    ITALIAN HILL ROAD.    DAY. KIP, the Sikh Lieutenant, and HARDY, his sergeant, explor ahead of the becalmed convoy, using saucer-like METAL DET HEADSETS.  Kip is young, lithe, contained, utterly focuse along the debris-strewn road.  He stiffens as he register a bayonet he carefully scrapes at the mud-caked surface. GLEAMS.  Suddenly, A PAIR OF FEET walks across his vision HURRIES PAST, walking carelessly up the road.  It's so su neither man registers at first, and then Kip is shouting.
Hey!  Hey!  Stop!  Hey!
Don't move!  Stand ABSOLUTELY STILL! Hana stops.  Hardy gingerly follows her footsteps.
(as he approaches)
Good, that's good, just stay still for me and then we're going to be fine. He arrives at Hana.  Then grabs her.  He'd like to slap h

What are you doing?!  What the bloody  hell do you think you're doing? By way of an answer she looks at the ground ahead of her BRACELET lies in the mud.  Hardy bends down and collects bracelet, presses it into Hana's hands. 11        EXT.    VILLAGE.    DUSK. The CONVOY is threading through A RUINED VILLAGE, passing of war.  An overturned vehicle now used as a game by some dejected refugees tramping along the side of the road.  F one of the buildings are hanging HALF A DOZEN CORPSES, st down with crude placards denouncing, in Italian, their co with the Nazis. 12        INT.    RED CROSS TRUCK.    CONTINUOUS. Hana sees all this as she sits blankly inside the truck, swaying alongside her.  She puts out her hand to steady h 13*.        EXT.    CONVOY SITE, ITALY.    DUSK. THE CONVOY is making a PITSTOP.  The trucks are silhouett Hana helps lift the Patient's stretcher onto the ground. him.
Do you need something? The Patient nods.  Hana gets up to prepare MORPHINE INJEC small kit.  Mary arrives.  Touches Hana gently, conscious for Jan's death.
Are you okay?  Oh God, Hana, you were like sisters.
(sighs angrily)
We keep moving him - in and out of the truck.  Why?  He's dying.  What's the point?

Well, we can't hardly leave him.  Do you mean leave him?  We can't. Hana has settled down beside the Patient's stretcher.  Sh herself up against the night.  On the hill above, she can outline of A SMALL MONASTERY in the moonlight.  She's cry a frozen mask.

I must be a curse.  Anybody who loves me, anybody who gets close to me - or I must be cursed.  Which is it? The Patient laces her fingers into his crabbed hand. 14        EXT.    THE MONASTERY.    DAY. Hana is investigating the MONASTERY OF ST. ANNA, wanderin overgrown gardens, past a pond.  What sanctuary it seems 15*.        INT.    THE MONASTERY LIBRARY.    DAY. Hana explores via a gaping hole in a LIBRARY where the wa collapsed from shelling.  The garden intrudes, ivy curls shelves.  Bloated books lie abandoned, and there's a PIAN one side.  Hana presses the keys through the filthy tarpa covers it.  Everywhere there are signs of a brief German 15a*.        INT.    MONASTERY CLOISTERS.    DAY. Past the Library is a CLOISTERS, drenched with silver lig 15b*.        INT.    THE MONASTERY STAIRS.    DAY. Hana goes upstairs, negotiating a huge VOID in the stone thirds of the way up. 15c*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    DAY. She comes across a small CHAPEL, with the remains of mura altar pressed into service by the Germans as a table.  Ha old bed, and a mattress. 16        EXT.    THE MONASTERY GARDEN.    DAY. Hana comes out, passes a DRY WATER TROUGH.  She hears a r gravel and turns to see A TORTOISE ambling towards the tr there's A GURGLING SOUND.  THE HANDLELESS PUMP IS SUDDENL splashing water everywhere.  The Tortoise, clearly arrivi enjoys a welcome shower.  Hana goes to the trough, dips h the water.  Looks around her, and makes a decision. 17        EXT.    CONVOY SITE.    ITALY.    DAY. The Convoy is in the final stages of loading up.  Oliver vehicles, deep in dispute with a determined Hana, who is sacks of rice.
The war's over - you told me yourself. How can it be desertion?
It's not over everywhere.  I didn't mean literally.
When he dies I'll catch up. Oliver hovers as Hana adds the rice to a small cache of p then lays another blanket over the Patient.
It's not safe here.  The whole country's crawling with Bandits and Germans and God knows what.  It's madness.  I can't allow it. You're not, this is natural - it's shock.   For all of us.  Hana -
I need morphine.  A lot.  And a pistol.
(clutching at straws)
And what if he really is a spy?
(impatiently)
He can't even move.
If anything happened to you I'd never forgive myself. Hana nods.  A tiny smile.  Oliver shrugs helplessly.

We're heading for Leghorn.  Livorno the Italians call it.  We'll expect you. 18*.        INT.    THE MONASTERY.    DAY. TWO SOLDIERS are helping Mary and Hana carry the Patient monastery.  Hana indicates the stairs.

Up there. They struggle up the stairs, one of the Soldiers gasping avoids falling into the void in the stairs.  The cot almo which the Patient SUDDENLY SPEAKS, his voice cracked and still clearly aristocratic.
There was a Prince, who was dying, and he was carried up the tower at Pisa so he could die with a view of the Tuscan Hills. Am I that Prince? Hana laughs.
Because you're leaning?  No, you're  just on an angle.  You're too heavy! Mary laughs.  They reach the landing.  Hana kicks open th CHAPEL.

In here. 18a*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    DAY. Hana lets Mary take the weight while she goes to the bed the drapes, sending up a cloud of dust.  They lower the P the bed.  She turns to the SOLDIERS.
Thank you. She shuts the door on them, leaving Mary staring aghast a its faded frescoes, its mold, its chaos.  Hana smiles, op to let a fierce envelope of light into the room.
Good. She goes to Mary and hugs her.

text: 19a*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    DAY. HANA walks down to the Patient's Room and stands in the d Patient turns his head to her.  He's grinning.  He puts u the track a song begins:  Some Other Time.

THE SONG CONTINUED IN THE DESERT where we find the singer MADOX, a weather-beaten man who is working on the guts of TIGER MOTH AEROPLANE.  His face is blackened with oil.  A European, ALMASY, stands beside him, holding tools and a camshaft.  Madox yanks out a perished rubber hose and hol Almasy to inspect.  Behind them is an ENCAMPMENT - some c in the meager scrub, half a dozen black tents of the BEDO and servants to the Almasy/Madox Expedition.  It's 1938 a continent is full of such expeditions, competing with eac pursuing lost treasures, sources of rivers, hidden cities D'AGOSTINO, the team's Italian ARCHEOLOGIST, drives towar in one of the expedition's adapted FORD MOTORCARS.  He ge carrying a large earthenware WATER JAR.  He looks very pl himself as he shows the jar to Almasy and then passes it
Thirsty?
(sniffing inside)
What's this?
Don't drink it! He reaches for the jug, then pours out a little sludge - brackish and stinks.  Madox makes a face.
I can't guarantee the vintage, my  friends.  I just dug it out of the hill. Madox and Almasy have seen many such jugs.
Excellent.  That's terrific, D'Ag. (to Almasy, of a tool)
Toss that up, would you.
(mischievously)
There are some others. 21        EXT.    POTTERY HILL.    DAY.

text: D'Agostino emerges over the brow of a dune, leading Madox The other members of the team are already there - BERMANN PHOTOGRAPHER and FOUAD, EGYPTOLOGIST from Cairo.
(to Almasy, astonished)
My God, look at this! They bend to touch the jars, literally hundreds of them, piled on top of each other.  Bermann approaches them, car tripod.
Incredible, Hmm?  Quite incredible.
I've never seen anything like it.  There  would have been enough water here to serve an army.
(gloomily)
Which means we're in the wrong place. Almasy speaks with a slight but unmistakable European acc
Why?
Would you stockpile water near to an Oasis?  There can't be a natural spring within fifty miles of here.
Or they didn't know of one.
So, it may not be Zerzura, still incredible.
(nodding, delighted)
A pottery hill!
A wild goose chase.
(firmly)
No. Almasy gives him a look.  But Madox will have none of it.
No.  Now we look in the other places. We're eliminating. The unmistakable buzz of AN AEROPLANE distracts them.

Good, and here comes reinforcements. 21a*.        EXT.    BASE CAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    DAY. LATER and a smart new aeroplane, a STEERMAN, makes a smoo the flat desert.  The expedition team drives over to meet Almasy is not with them.  He's walking, apparently not so A young, kissed and newly-married couple emerge from the are GEOFFREY AND KATHARINE CLIFTON. And it's immediately clear that Katharine is the woman in crash at the beginning of the film. Madox makes all the introductions.  Hands are shaken, hel as the couple disembark in their leather flying gear.  Ge his helmet and, in what we will come to know as an ubiqui produces a bottle of CHAMPAGNE and sets off the cork with
I hereby Christen us the International Sand Club! 22        EXT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    LATE DAY. The party is in the shade of the tents.  Almasy joins the nods over to the Clifton plane.
Marvelous plane.  Did you look?
(beaming at Almasy)
Isn't it?  Wedding present from Katharine's parents.  I'm calling it Rupert Bear.  Hello.  Geoffrey Clifton.
We can finally consign my old bird to the scrapheap. Almasy smiles and walks on towards the others.
Mrs. Clifton - Count Almasy.
(smiling, offering her hand)
Geoffrey gave me your monograph when I was reading up on the desert. Very impressive.
(stiff)
Thank you.
I wanted to meet a man who could write such a long paper with so few adjectives.
A thing is still a thing no matter what you place in front of it.  Big car, slow car, chauffeur-driven car, still a car.
(joining them and joining in)
A broken car?
Still a car.
(hands them champagne)
Not much use, though.
Love?  Romantic love, platonic love, filial love - ?  Quite different things, surely?
(hugging Katharine)
Uxoriousness - that's my favorite kind of love.  Excessive love of one's wife.
(a dry smile)
There you have me.

text: The morning floods into the room.  The Patient lies, lost desert.  Then a sudden CLATTERING NOISE disturbs him. 24        INT.   STAIRS, THE MONASTERY.   DAY. Hana is dropping armfuls of books into the cavities of th stairs, and with others, she is improvising new steps.  T volumes are perfect for treading on. 25        INT.   LIBRARY.   DAY. Hana comes in, gathers up another armful of books and car to continue her stair repairs. 26*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    DAY. Hana enters.
What was all the banging?  Were you fighting rats or the entire German army?
I was repairing the stairs.  I found a library and the books were very useful. Hana shrugs.  She's attending to him, pulling back the sh up the pillows.  He's short of breath.
Before you find too many uses for these books would you read some to me?
I think they're all in Italian, but I'll look, yes.  What about your own book?
(reluctant)
My book?  The Herodotus?  Yes, we can read him. Hana picks up the book and hands it to him.  Then she sta in her pockets.
Oh - I've found plums.  We have plums in the orchard.  We have an orchard! She has peeled a plum and now slips it into his mouth.
Thank you. His mouth works with the pleasure of the taste, a little from the mouth.  Hana mops it up.
The plumness of this plum. A noise, GURGLING sound, disturbs them.

What's that? 27        INT/EXT.    THE MONASTERY.    DAY. Hana comes through the Cloisters into the garden as the g increases.  She's in time to catch the TORTOISE arriving the WATER TROUGH just as it starts to gush with water.  S to The Patient's open window.
Water! (bends to the Tortois)

You hear it, too, don't you! 28        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    DAY. Close on the HERODOTUS.  The Patient opens its cover, hel leather ties.  Loose PAPERS, PHOTOGRAPHS, HAND-DRAWN MAPS are all collected between the pages.  He claws at some wa which appear to be based on CAVE PAINTINGS - figures, dar warriors of the stone age, some with bows in their hands, plumes in their hair - arranged in abstract patterns unca those of Matisse.  Some appear to be swimming, another is the Patient loses control of the papers and the whole par the floor with a crack. 29        INT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    DUSK. A SHOT RINGS OUT, disturbing the evening meal.  Almasy an outside.  Silhouetted on a ridge, a group of men sit astr One of them holds his rifle aloft, clearly pointing towar means friend.  Fouad peers at the horizon.
European, I think, with guides.
(can only see shapes)
How do you know?
(frowns)

Yes, and I think I know who this is. 30        EXT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    DUSK. ALMASY AND MADOX WALK OUT TO INTERCEPT THE ARRIVALS as th dismounts, the procession of camels splaying out as if in Almasy speaks in Arabic, exchanging the ritual greetings. DURING THIS, FENELON-BARNES, sole European in this expedi finally persuaded his camel to sit, and dismounts irritab the animal in disgust.
Ugly brute.  Shits and roars and complains all day. (bypassing Almasy and
approaching Madox) Of course, you have your aeroplane.   Two now!  Do you still call yourselves explorers?  I assume not.
(stiffly)
Fenelon-Barnes.

Yes, I think a sailor can call himself an explorer, can't he?  Or should Columbus have swum to America? 31        INT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    DUSK. The arrivals come inside.  Madox handles the introduction
I think you know all of us, except for Geoffrey and Katharine Clifton, who've recently come out from England.
Apprentices.
This is Clive Fenelon-Barnes.
(to Katharine)
I know your mother, of course.
Hello.
I'm also searching for the lost Oasis,  but by more authentic means.
(of Almasy)
Anyway, my friend here has a new theory - that Zerzura doesn't exist.  So we may all be chasing windmills.  Have some food.
Well, it's certainly not between here and Dakhla.  Nine days of nothing but sand and sandstorms.  An egg.  I found an ostrich egg and some fossils.
Isn't Zerzura supposed to be protected by spirits who take on the shape of sandstorms?
What kind of fossils?
I'll invite you to my paper at the Royal Geographical Society. Are you still a member? He takes a long drink from a bowl of frothing camel milk.
I think you know I am.
(ignoring Almasy)
Quite impossible, Madox.  You must know  that.  If you attempt to cross the Sand Sea due east of Kufra by car you'll leave your bones in the sand for me to collect.
(leaving the tent)
If you come across my bones - I hope you'll do me the honor of leaving  them in peace. (to Katharine)
Excuse me.
You have my word as a gentleman. (watching him leave)

I've discovered a unique type of sand-dune.  I've applied to the King for permission to call it  The Fenelon-Barnes Formation. 32        EXT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    NIGHT. LATER, supper over, the company is entertaining itself. Almasy, standing outside his tent, watches the merriment distance. D'Ag is nearing the end of a passionate rendition of  Puc Lucevan Le Stelle.  He sits down to much applause from th SPINS AN EMPTY CHAMPAGNE BOTTLE on the sand.  It comes to at Clifton who gets up, grinning, and plunges into Yes! W Bananas with great gusto.  His version involves CHANGING during each line of the chorus - prompted by Oui!  or Ja! the others.  Song finished, much bowing and guying, he sp and it arrives equidistant between Fenelon-Barnes and Kat with a little NUDGE from the husband it settles on his wi gets up, awkward.
I can't sing. (the audience groans)
but I can tell a story. (to Almasy, who has arrived)
I might need a prompt.  Do you have your Herodotus?  I've noticed you carry it...
I'm sorry - what have you noticed?
Your book.  Your Herodotus! Almasy looks uncomfortable.
(reacting quickly)
It doesn't matter.  Really.  I think I can muddle through.  Okay - The Story of  Candaules and Gyges.  King Candaules was passionately in love with his wife - (Geoffrey whistles proudly)
One day he said to Gyges, the son of somebody, anyway - his favorite warrior -
(quietly prompting her)
Daskylus...
(smiles)

Yes, thank you, Gyges, son of Daskylus - Candaules said to him I don't think you believe me when I tell you how beautiful my wife is.  And although Gyges replied he did find the Queen magnificent the King  insisted he would find some way to prove beyond dispute that she was fairest of all women.  Do you all know this story? The men all encourage her to continue her story. 33*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    NIGHT. - and Hana's voice CONTINUES THE STORY as she reads to th listens, eyes closed, still in the desert.
(reading from the Herodotus)
I will hide you in the room where  we sleep, said Candaules. She stumbles over the word.
Candaules
(not neurotic)
Candaules...you're laughing at me.
I'm not laughing at you.  Go on, please.

When my wife comes to lie down she always lays her garments one by one on a seat near the entrance of the room, and from where you stand you will be able to gaze on her at your leisure... 34*.        EXT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    NIGHT.
(her story continuing)

And that evening, it's exactly as the King had told him, she goes to the chair and removes her clothes, one by one,  until she stand naked in full view of Gyges.  And indeed she was more lovely than he could have imagined. Almasy stares at her, framed by the velvet black sky.  Ka to looks at him.

But then the Queen looked up and saw Gyges concealed in the shadows.   And though she said nothing, she shuddered. The next day she sent for Gyges and challenged him.  And hearing his story, she said this -
Off with his head!

death for gazing on that which you should not, or else kill my husband who shamed me and become King in his place. Clifton makes a face of outrage.  For Katherine the story collapsed.  She wants it to be finished.
So Gyges killed the King and married the Queen and became ruler of Lydia for twenty eight years.  The End. (an uncomfortable moment)
Do I spin the bottle? Almasy shrinks away from the fire, disappears into black.
(to Clifton)
And let that be a lesson to you! 35        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    NIGHT. Hana looks up from the Herodotus, sees the Patient's eyes Gently touches his face and whispers.
Are you asleep?
(lying)
Yes.  Dropping off. And Hana closes the book, gets up, and blows out the lamp

PITCH BLACK and then A TORCH flickers on as Almasy enters Barnes' tent.  He pulls apart his luggage, quickly and me He finds what he is looking for inside a trunk:  A LARGE BRANCH; a collection of stone leaves, wrapped in a piece Then he's distracted by a noise from Fenelon-Barnes' bed. stiffens, turns to investigate.  There's A LUMP in the co Almasy eases back the blanket to reveal a YOUNG GIRL, no fourteen, bound hand and foot.  He holds the torch to her 37        EXT.    BASECAMP AT POTTERY HILL.    MORNING. The next morning.  Almasy and Madox prepare to take off. Clifton's Rupert Bear taxis past them, a wave from Clifto Katharine.  Madox is very disturbed by what Almasy is tel
What did you think you were doing in his tent?
Looking for the fossils.  Why should we wait until we're in London?  This girl  was probably twelve years old.
(getting into the plane)
You shouldn't go into another man's tent. It's inexcusable.
Her hands and feet were tied.
What did you do?
I looked at them.  They're shrubs, small trees.  Exquisite.  And fossilized, rock hard. He walks away to the nose of the plane.
I was talking about the girl.
Cut the ropes.  I left a note, on his blanket. (gleefully)

At the next Geographical Society I  shall await with great interest the announcement of the Fenelon-Barnes Slave Knot.  The Girl wouldn't leave,  of course.  Her father had sold her for a camel. He turns over the propeller, the engine cranks up. 38        EXT.    GILF KEBIR PLATEAU.    MORNING. Both planes are scouting the Gilf Kebir region.  Geoffrey alongside Madox and wiggles his wings.  Madox waves. They're flying over a distinctive group of GRANITE MASSIF shaped hills.  The broken towers of the Gilf Kebir.  Alma distracted by them.  He turns to Madox and points down, i should explore them. Madox gestures to the Cliftons to PHOTOGRAPH the Massifs. from Geoffrey. 39*.        INT.    THE PATIENT'S ROOM.    MORNING. Hana gives the Patient his injection, now she begins to c sheet.  The light streams in from the open window.  She l green hills rolling away from the Monastery, the village distance.
I should try and move your bed.  I want you to be able to see the view.  It's good, it's a view from a monastery.
I can already see.
(bending down to his level)
How?  How can you see anything?
Not the window - I can't bear the light anyway - no, I can see all the way to  the desert.  I've found the lost fossils.
I'm turning you. An awkward moment as she rolls him on to his back.  He gr pain.  She washes him very tenderly.

Zerzura, the White City of Acacias, the Oasis of Little Birds.  As me about the scent of acacia - it's in this room.  I can smell it.  The taste of tea so black it falls into your mouth.  I can taste it. I'm chewing the mint.  Is there sand in my eyes?  Are you cleaning sand from my ears?
No sand.  That's your drugs speaking.
I can see my wife in that view.
Are you remembering more?
Could I have a cigarette?
Are you crazy?
